distributional 0.3.0.9000
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Sampling distribution

Source: R/dist_sample.R
dist_sample.Rd

dist_sample(x)

Arguments

x

A list of sampled values.

Examples

# Univariate numeric samples
dist <- dist_sample(x = list(rnorm(100), rnorm(100, 10)))

dist
#> <distribution[2]>
#> [1] sample[100] sample[100]
mean(dist)
#> [1] -0.03363001  9.94033840
variance(dist)
#> [1] 1.0079093 0.9095014
skewness(dist)
#> [1] -0.54313832 -0.08668177
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1]  1.4953125  0.6372796 -0.6541586 -0.2799015  1.1480048 -0.6541586
#>  [7] -0.2227996  1.3238077  0.6195175 -0.4353646
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1]  9.158316  8.577413 10.336136 10.104188  8.683455  9.158316  9.075717
#>  [8]  9.699167  8.883210  9.990509
#> 

density(dist, 1)
#> [1] 0.2783344 0.0000000

# Multivariate numeric samples
dist <- dist_sample(x = list(cbind(rnorm(100), rnorm(100, 10))))

dist
#> <distribution[1]>
#> [1] sample[100]
mean(dist)
#> [1]  0.0283298 10.1076228
variance(dist)
#>           [,1]      [,2]
#> [1,] 1.2537471 0.1632231
#> [2,] 0.1632231 1.1515685
skewness(dist)
#> [1] -0.005761191
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>             [,1]      [,2]
#>  [1,]  1.4129201 10.576943
#>  [2,] -1.3408685  8.845841
#>  [3,] -0.6068936  9.210703
#>  [4,]  1.5861789 11.750793
#>  [5,]  0.3952318 10.253854
#>  [6,] -0.9560627 11.728988
#>  [7,] -1.0301386 11.825324
#>  [8,] -1.6099467 11.745368
#>  [9,]  0.2248624 10.455571
#> [10,] -1.0634917 10.880304
#> 

density(dist, 1)
#> [1] 0.2462366 0.0000000
